sourceDesc.p: Information on named entities in this file has been extracted from files in the Digital Mitford Archive.

person.note: A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford. Date unknown. More research needed.

A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford between 1837 and 1854. Poet and authoress. Supposedly wrote her work Costanza between the ages of 15 and 17. This may be the anonymously published Costanza of Mistra: a tale of Modern Greece: in five cantos in 1839. Spouse of the Rev. William Edwards Partridge (1837-51); daughter of Thomas Oliver and Maria Anderdon.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford. Date unknown. Surname unknown. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford around the 1830's. Forename unknown. More research needed.
Spouse of Francis Bennoch. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1855. More research needed.

One of the wealthiest commoners in Berkshire and a major landowner and philanthropist. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford; Mitford wrote a sonnet, Englefield House: The Seat of R. Benyon De Beauvoir, Esq., Near Reading, printed in her 1827 Poems. He served as a Justice of the Peace, Deputy Lieutenant for Berkshire, and as High Sheriff of Berkshire.

A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford, date unknown. Forename unknown. An undated letter was sent by Mitford to Mrs. Blandy at Three Mile Cross, near Reading, along with an engraved portrait of Mitford herself. More research needed.

A mentee and correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford between 1845 and 1855. Author of Chamois Hunting in the Alps, as well as other works of travel writing. He tutored the two elder sons of John Constable, the painter, with whom he became close friends. He traveled throughout Germany and Austria, and studied the German language. His translations of the fairy tales of Hans Christian Anderson did much to popularize them with English-speaking audiences. Some of Mitford's letters to Boner, many of which offer constructive criticism of Boner's work, appear in Rosa Kettle's Memoirs and Letters of Charles Boner, published in 1871.

Publisher, bookseller, and anonymous author of children's fiction. Partner of Charles Tilt from 1840 to 1843 before buying the firm for himself. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1837. Source: WorldCat.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1834. Forename unknown. More research needed.

Failing to qualify for his medical studies, he began tutoring and traveling before he began to publish works. Longtime secretary of the Royal Literary Fund. A committed Anglican, at the age of twenty-two, he wrote A Treatise on the Happiness Arising from the Exercise of the Christian Faith. A frequent contributor to periodicals, he also edited the news section of Gardiner's Chronicle for twenty-nine years. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1843.

Sketcher and lithographer, as well as author of Memorials of the Life of Amelia Opie, as well as of many didactic biographies for children. She authored more than twenty mainly biographical works between 1854 and 1857, some of which were published by the Religious Tract Society. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1854.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford, date unknown. Forename unknown. Mitford signed an autograph poem to a Miss Brooks, titled Song. More research needed.
Sister of poet Mary Ann Browne (1812-1844). Mary Russell Mitford wrote in an album belonging to her in 1829. More research needed.

birth.placeName: New York City, New York, USA

death.placeName: New York City, New York, USA

person.note: Author of three books on American frontier life: New Home; Who'll Follow?, Forest Life, and Western Clearings. Served as editor of the Union Magazine from 1847 to 1849. Particularly after her husband's death in 1846, her home became an important literary salon in New York City.

Actor active between 1811 and 1859; played at Drury Lane and other London theatres, as well as on circuits in York and Lincoln. Also served as stage manager at Drury Lane. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1828.

Began his career as a stockbroker and became wealthy through investments in railroads, mining, and British colonial land. Liberal Member of Parliament and owner of the Liberal Morning Chronicle newspaper between 1834 and 1847.

Conservative Member of Parliament, High Sheriff of Berkshire, and Chairman of the Berkshire Quarter Sessions. He changed his name to Richard Fellowes Benyon after inheriting his uncle Richard Benyon De Beauvoir's estate, including Englefield House in 1854.

Story writer for Household Words and other periodicals. Notable works include the poems After visiting Exeter Cathedral and Father and Son. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford between 1852 and 1853.

Expert linguist and translator in Italian, French, German, and Hebrew. Founded the Jews' Infant School, London, authored numerous educational pamphlets, and supported other charitable institutions. With her father, Isaac Lyon Goldsmid, helped to found and support University College, London and the West London Synagogue of British Jews. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1852.

death.placeName: Devon Lodge, East Moulsey, Surrey, England

person.note: Novelist and short story writer; her stories and sketches set in Ireland were compared to those of Mary Russell Mitford. Her first book, Sketches of Irish Character, is a collection that reflects on her Irish childhood. Editor of the Juvenile Forget-me-Not from 1829, as well as Sharpe's London Magazine between 1852 and 1853, and the St James's Magazine between 1861 and 1868, where she also published serial fiction. Spouse of Samuel Carter Hall, she published under the name Mrs. S. C. [Samuel Carter] Hall. A correspondent of Mitford between 1829 and 1830.
Prolific poet, short story writer, translator, editor, and memoirist; her spouse William Howitt was occasionally her co-author. A correspondent of Mitford between 1834 and 1846.
Playwright, poet, translator, and editor. Married Thomas Brand, 20th Baron Dacre in 1819. A correspondent of Mitford between 1836 and 1839.

Prolific miscellaneous writer and editor, especially of history, biography, and criticism. Editor of the Poetical Register, which ran from 1801 to 1814 and often featured reviews of poetical compilations as well as examples of his own verse. Also a contributor of The British Poets (1822) and contributor and editor of the Annual Register. His own compilations include New Elegant Extracts (1823-27) and The Commonplace Book of Epigrams (1825). Married Selina Granville Wheler, daughter of Captain Charles Granville Wheler. A correspondent of Mitford between 1811 and 1830.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford between 1840 and 1847. Forename unknown. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford. Forename unknown. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1855. Forename unknown. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1852. Forename unknown. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1837. Forename unknown. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1835. Forename unknown. More research needed.

Clergyman and prolific editor, translator, literary historian, and book collector. He helped to found the Pery Society and the Shakespeare Society in 1840. A correspondent of Mitford between 1828 and 1854.

Solicitor and prolific translator, and essayist. Became joint editor with W.F. Cornish of the Law Magazine, or, Quarterly Review of Jurisprudence in June 1828. After the fourth number, he became sole editor and continued in his position until June 1844. Served as chief leader writer for the Morning Chronicle and was a frequent contributor to the Edinburgh Review and the Quarterly. Some of his works include The Art of Dining (1852) and Biographical and Critical Essays (2 vols., 1874) A correspondent of Mitford between 1834 and 1839.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1844. Forename unknown. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford, date unknown. More research needed.
Writer active between 1823 and 1827. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1836. Source: WorldCat

Writer, editor, and horticulturalist active between 1839 and 1871. Editor of the The Royal Lady's Magazine: and Archives of the Court of St. James's from 1831, later retitled the Horticultural Journal, Florists' Register, and Royal Lady's Magazine, new series, beginning in 1839. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford between 1831 and 1832. Source: DNB, WorldCat
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford, date unknown. Forename unknown. Mitford wrote an undated letter to him in the third person. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1831. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1838. Forename unknown. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1836. Forename unknown. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford, date unknown. Forename unknown. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1837. Forename unknown. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1829; letter addressed to her at Arbor Rectory in Reading. Forename unknown. More research needed.

Clergyman who was also a poet, translator, naturalist, and botanical illustrator. Member of Parliament for Hampshire and for Cricklade. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1810. Her 1810 Poems contain a dedicatory poemto him.
[mother of sir thomas croft, , son of sir richard croft, nephew of Sophia Baillie/related to Joanna] [Margaret Denman? widow of sir richard]

A patient of Mr. Sherwood. May be Henry Duckinfield (note alternate spelling), vicar of St. Giles from 1814-1834, according to a handwritten note at the bottom of the same page on which Needham has typed Dukinfield's name.

date.placeName: Three Mile Cross, Shinfield, Berkshire, England

note.p: George Mitford was born on November 15, 1760 in Hexham, Northumberland, the son of Francis Midford, surgeon, and Jane Graham. He was related to the Mitfords of Mitford Castle, Northumberland. In 1784, he was living in Alresford and is listed in a Hampshire directory as "surgeon (medicine)." Although later sources would claim that he was a graduate of the University of Edinburgh medical school, there is no evidence that he obtained a medical degree; his father and grandfather worked as surgeon-apothecaries and it seems likely that he served a medical apprenticeship with family members. He married Mary Russell on October 17, 1785 at New Alresford, Hampshire. On the marriage allegation papers, both gave their addresses as Old Alresford; they later came to live at Broad Street in New Alresford. Their only child to live to adulthood, Mary Russell Mitford, was born two years later on December 16, 1787 at New Alresford, Hampshire. George Mitford died on December 11, 1842 at Three Mile Cross in the parish of Shinfield, Berkshire.

person.note:
Known as K. or "my K.", she was named Kerenhappuch after the third of Job’s daughters (Job, 42:14). Hired as a servant maid for the Mitford household in 1840 until she became embroiled in a scandal with the birth of her illegitimate son, James Henry Taylor, in 1844 and was promptly dismissed. Part of the controversy involved rumors that the child was the son of George Mitford. Scholars have disagreed about whether this was the case, although William Roberts claimed to have heard it from J.H. Taylor himself. Regardless, Miss Mitford would take K. back the following year, and she stayed in service until Miss Mitford’s death in 1855. Sources: Needham Papers, Reading Central Library. Alexandra Drayton, Unearthing Our Village.
"Capers With K" . 13 March 2013. See .

Travel writer, translator, and editor. Editor of The Juvenile Keepsake. Contributed nine annual volumes to the Landscape Annual between 1830 and 1838. His work, Life of Michael Angelo, was published in 1831. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1829.

death.placeName: Manhattan, New York City, New York, USA

person.note: American travel writer, essayist, and editor. Surname also spelled "Tuckermann." Was active in New York City's literary cirle after 1845. Along with volumes of verse and prose alike, he also contributed to The Knickerbocker magazine. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1853.
Novelist, travel writer, editor, and historian-biographer. Along with many published books, she contributed to Fraser's Magazine and the Illuminated Magazine, as well as several annuals.

A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford between 1830 and 1835. Founder, with Henry Colburn, of the New Monthly Magazine. Editor for Rudolph Ackermann of Repository of the Arts, the Forget-Me-Not, and the Juvenile Forget-Me-Not. Printer and publisher of the Conservative Cornwall Gazette, Falmouth Packet, and Plymouth Journal.
Spouse of Frederic Shoberl. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1849.
Father of Elizabeth Barrett-Browning. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1850.
Sister of Elizabeth Barrett-Browning and her frequent correspondent. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1839.

person.birth: 4 March 1809 Upper Berkeley Street, London, England
person.note: Sister of Elizabeth Barrett-Browning. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1839.

A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in the 1830s. Forename unknown. A letter to her from MRM is addressed to Three Mile Cross, of estimated date recorded in the 1830s, now held at Boston Public Library British Civilization Collection, 1573-1970, Folder Ms.Eng.170: Letters of Mary Russell Mitford, 182?-184?, Item 6.

A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford. Forename unknown. Two letters to her in our database from MRM are addressed to Three Mile Cross, of estimated date recorded in the 1820s, now held at Boston Public Library British Civilization Collection, 1573-1970, Folder Ms.Eng.170: Letters of Mary Russell Mitford, 182?-184?, Items 4 and 5. More research needed.

Forename unknown. A letter from MRM is addressed to R. Rigsby at Three Mile Cross, of 1 August 1847, now held at Boston Public Library British Civilization Collection, 1573-1970, Folder Ms.Eng.170: Letters of Mary Russell Mitford, 182?-184?, Item 8. More research needed
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1847. Letter addressed to Bear Wood, Wokingham. More research needed
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford, date unknown. More research needed.

A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1824. Letter addressed to Newbold, Chesterfield, Derbyshire. Forename unknown. Possibly the mother of Col. Frederick Stovin, as the address and name match on a letter written to his mother on 5 December 1814. A letter from Mary Russell Mitford of 2 November 1824 to Mrs. Stovin reveals that she is a mutual friend of Miss James.

Forename unknown. A letter to her from MRM is addressed to Three Mile Cross, of estimated date recorded in the 1840s, now held at Boston Public Library British Civilization Collection, 1573-1970, Folder Ms.Eng.170: Letters of Mary Russell Mitford, 182?-184?, Item 12. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford, date unknown. Letter addressed to W. F. White, Esq. Forename unknown. More research needed.

Radical politician and Member of Parliament for Okehampton from 1807 to 1812. With Francis Burdett, Wardle was instrumental in prosecuting the Duke of York-Mary Ann Clarke controversy. Mitford addressed a poem to him, "To G. L. Wardle, Esq., on the Death of His Child".

death.placeName: New York City, New York, USA

person.note: Influential American reviewer and critic; also editor of compilations of English and American poetry, as well as magazines including Vanity Fair, and a collection of the works of Edgar Allan Poe. Contributed to the Union Magazine, the Knickerbocker Magazine, Putnam's Monthly Magazine, and the New York Evening Post. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1853 and also a friend of Nathaniel Hawthorne.
Irish poet and playwright; friend of Maria Edgeworth. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford between 1852 and 1854.

Church of England clergyman and writer. Noted for his translations of Greek and Latin poems. Wrote the radical farce Reform: a Farce, Modernised from Aristophanes under the name 'S. Foot Jr.', which was published in 1792. A friend of Wordsworth, the two had planned to collaborate on a book of satirical poems, but it never materialized. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford between 1825 and 1830.
Protagonist and pseudonymous author of John Gibson Lockhart's 1819 novel, Peter's Letters to his Kinfolk.

Memoirist, travel writer, and writer on art. Nearly all her work was written about or for women, yet she was never considered a feminist. Her first publication, The Diary of an Ennuyée (1862), first appeared anonymously as A Lady's Diary and was her only attempt at fiction writing. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1838 and also a friend of Elizabeth Barrett Browning.

Prolific and celebrated social protest novelist and travel writer. Author of The Domestic Manners of the Americans, as well as anti-slavery and industrial novels. A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford between 1826 and 1852 and also a friend of Elizabeth Barrett Browning.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1840. Forename unknown. Likely the daughter of Mrs. Yates. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1835. Forename unknown. Likely the mother of Miss Yates. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1837. Forename unknown. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford, date unknown. Forename unknown. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1831. Forename unknown. More research needed.
A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1842. Forename unknown. More research needed.
